items.stem: What is a common route for contamination in a kitchen?
items.rationale: Poor hand hygiene spreads germs quickly between surfaces and food.
Hair is a physical contaminant; microbes and chemicals are other hazard types.

items.stem: The UK temperature danger zone is typically between:
items.rationale: Food kept between 5 °C and 63 °C allows harmful bacteria to multiply rapidly.

items.stem: Hot holding should be at or above:
items.rationale: 63 °C or hotter keeps food out of the danger zone during service.

options: Use one cloth for all tasks
Store raw meat below ready-to-eat food
items.rationale: Storing raw foods below ready-to-eat foods prevents drips contaminating safe food.

items.stem: Which board is commonly used for raw meat in UK colour coding?
items.rationale: Red chopping boards are typically reserved for raw meat in UK kitchens.

items.stem: When must food handlers wash hands?
options: After using the toilet and after handling raw food
Only at the start of shift
items.rationale: Key moments include after the toilet and after handling raw food to remove microbes.

items.stem: Which item is suitable PPE in a kitchen?
items.rationale: Hair restraints prevent shedding into food; jewellery and loose items are hazards.

items.stem: How many major allergens must be declared in the UK?
items.rationale: UK law requires declaration of 14 specified allergens.

items.stem: A customer asks about allergens. What should you do?
options: Check the up-to-date allergen matrix and labels
Say all dishes may contain all allergens
items.rationale: Always verify allergen information using the latest matrix or recipe specification.

items.stem: What is the second stage in a two-stage clean?
options: Apply disinfectant and leave for contact time
items.rationale: Stage two is to disinfect the surface and allow the chemical to stay wet for the full contact time.

options: Store bins next to ready-to-eat food
Empty only at end of day
items.rationale: Keeping bins lined and closed controls odours and pests.

options: Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points
items.rationale: HACCP is the internationally recognised Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points system.

options: Taking reasonable precautions and keeping records
items.rationale: Due diligence means taking all reasonable precautions and recording evidence.

options: Where food came from and where it goes
items.rationale: Traceability tracks food one step back to suppliers and one step forward to customers.
